reporting-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

title.narrative: The CITES (the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora) Sponsored Delegates. Sponsoring developing country delegates

description.narrative: Ensure that the environment and the natural resources upon which human lives and livelihoods depend are managed in ways that sustain productivity growth, a healthy population, as well as the intrinsic spiritual and cultural value of the environment.

This award strives to ensure that the environment and the natural resources upon which human lives and livelihoods depend are managed in ways that sustain productivity growth, a healthy population, as well as the intrinsic spiritual and cultural value of the environment. More specifically, this award includes CITES CoP18 (Conference of the Parties) Sponsored Delegates Project: Sponsoring developing country delegates to participate in the 18th meeting of the Conference of the Parties to CITES (the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora) in Colombo, 23 May - 3 June 2018.. CITES CoP18 Sponsored Delegates Project: Sponsoring developing country delegates to participate in the 18th meeting of the Conference of the Parties to CITES (Colombo, 23 May - 3 June 2018).

This sector captures the U.S. Government contributions to the multilateral development banks (e.g. World Bank, regional development banks). These contributions are made to international institutions with governmental membership which conduct all or a significant part of their activities in favor of development and aid recipient [Country]. They include multilateral development banks, United Nations agencies, and regional groupings (e.g. certain European Union and Arab agencies). Note: In most instances, International Contributions made by U.S. Government agencies (e.g. State, USAID) are mapped to the existing sector framework (e.g. economic development, environment etc...) and captured under the respective sector. Therefore, this sector currently only captures international contributions managed by the Department of Treasury ('Treasury'), in addition to U.S. Government contributions to trust funds for climate change and food security housed at the World Bank.
